content.raw:
This is not used anywhere. What is its purpose?

If it is used it needs to have a better name. `object` is a real type of object and this is too close for potential future bugs.
content.html:
This is not used anywhere. What is its purpose?

If it is used it needs to have a better name. object is a real type of object and this is too close for potential future bugs.

content.raw:
Object is used as a general object for sections which have yet to be implemented, such as DT. These would be inputted plainly as str, rather than having a class to handle their format automatically. 

In the future, there are plans to have these classes inherit from here, though for now this is our workaround. There seems to be a lack of possible names from the gmtk manual, which is why Object was settled on, is there a more appropriate name?
content.html:
Object is used as a general object for sections which have yet to be implemented, such as DT. These would be inputted plainly as str, rather than having a class to handle their format automatically.

In the future, there are plans to have these classes inherit from here, though for now this is our workaround. There seems to be a lack of possible names from the gmtk manual, which is why Object was settled on, is there a more appropriate name?

content.raw:
“The overall input master file is represented by a collections.OrderedDict subclass. Ordering should not be necessary for operation, but means more consistent output for testing purposes.”

This is not clear to me since the only object that inherits from OrderedDict is `Section`. Is “Section” the main class holding other subsections?
content.html:
“The overall input master file is represented by a collections.OrderedDict subclass. Ordering should not be necessary for operation, but means more consistent output for testing purposes.”

This is not clear to me since the only object that inherits from OrderedDict is Section. Is “Section” the main class holding other subsections?

content.raw: In general the kind types should be constants outside the class definitions. Something as simple as `DENSE_CPT_KIND=”DENSE_CPT”`
content.html: In general the kind types should be constants outside the class definitions. Something as simple as DENSE_CPT_KIND=”DENSE_CPT”

content.raw: This PR could really use some \(unit\) tests to at least get a better idea to get a whole picture on how this module would work at generating input master [files.](http://files.It) It’s not completely clear still from the example exactly how it all comes together. It would also help reduce any potential existing and future bug anxiety.
content.html: This PR could really use some (unit) tests to at least get a better idea to get a whole picture on how this module would work at generating input master files. It’s not completely clear still from the example exactly how it all comes together. It would also help reduce any potential existing and future bug anxiety.

content.raw:
In general, it would be great if all methods didn’t require their inputs to be iterables even for a single item. The amount of brackets for lists or tuples is a little bewildering to keep track of.

It would also be great if there was support for `__setattr__` / `__getattr__` and/or `__getitem__` / `__setitem__` as alternative syntax to manipulate gmtk objects by their name. e.g. `input_master.generic_input_object = Object("basic decision string", "DT")`. Or using the “key” notation with something like `input_master['generic_input_object']`.
content.html:
In general, it would be great if all methods didn’t require their inputs to be iterables even for a single item. The amount of brackets for lists or tuples is a little bewildering to keep track of.

It would also be great if there was support for __setattr__ / __getattr__ and/or __getitem__ / __setitem__ as alternative syntax to manipulate gmtk objects by their name. e.g. input_master.generic_input_object = Object("basic decision string", "DT"). Or using the “key” notation with something like input_master['generic_input_object'].

content.raw: I’m not quite sure I understand what you want here. Are you looking to be able to recall input.master sections from the main class. So to find all DT sections, use a command like input\_master\[“DT”\]? Or am I not getting it?
content.html: I’m not quite sure I understand what you want here. Are you looking to be able to recall input.master sections from the main class. So to find all DT sections, use a command like input_master[“DT”]? Or am I not getting it?

content.raw: The idea being that sections, being an OrderedDict, should be able to be referenced from the master InputMaster as well. For example from the test case below, `input_master["example_cpt"]` would refer to the `InlineSection([("example_cpt", DenseCPT([[0.5, 0.5]]))])` object and may be updated, read, etc.
content.html: The idea being that sections, being an OrderedDict, should be able to be referenced from the master InputMaster as well. For example from the test case below, input_master["example_cpt"] would refer to the InlineSection([("example_cpt", DenseCPT([[0.5, 0.5]]))]) object and may be updated, read, etc.

content.raw: This issue is that InputMasters are composed of several InlineSections, which are the actual ordered dicts. So you would only be able to do input\_master\[0\]\[“example\_cpt”\] in this case. InputMaster is a subclass of list.
content.html: This issue is that InputMasters are composed of several InlineSections, which are the actual ordered dicts. So you would only be able to do input_master[0][“example_cpt”] in this case. InputMaster is a subclass of list.

content.raw:
The idea would be that, for example, `__getattr__` would traverse the list, tree, etc to find the object. In this case it would iterate over each `Section` object and attempt the lookup.

Alternatively you could have `InputMaster` inherit from an `OrderedDict` and use the `DENSE_CPT_KIND` types \(maybe a different name?\) used a keys to lookup the relevant sections. This might make something like `input_master[DENSE_CPT][“example_cpt”]` possible.
content.html:
The idea would be that, for example, __getattr__ would traverse the list, tree, etc to find the object. In this case it would iterate over each Section object and attempt the lookup.

Alternatively you could have InputMaster inherit from an OrderedDict and use the DENSE_CPT_KIND types (maybe a different name?) used a keys to lookup the relevant sections. This might make something like input_master[DENSE_CPT][“example_cpt”] possible.

content.raw: Can you clarify what this is supposed to be accomplishing?
content.html: Can you clarify what this is supposed to be accomplishing?

content.raw: This uses the interface of the numpy array input, instead of trying to use the more difficult ndarray interface. This line specifically will turn the input list, or list of lists into an array and then pass it to the array\_finalize function of the given subclass, cls.
content.html: This uses the interface of the numpy array input, instead of trying to use the more difficult ndarray interface. This line specifically will turn the input list, or list of lists into an array and then pass it to the array_finalize function of the given subclass, cls.

content.raw: @{5ac790531b5dd37ea53a123d} this is ready for your revision and feedback
content.html: @Matthew McNeil this is ready for your revision and feedback

content.raw: This reads like it should be replacing the first element in the input\_master list, namely the “example\_cpt” inline section. But looking at the reference it doesn’t seem like that’s the case. What is supposed be happening here and why would you use it over an append?
content.html: This reads like it should be replacing the first element in the input_master list, namely the “example_cpt” inline section. But looking at the reference it doesn’t seem like that’s the case. What is supposed be happening here and why would you use it over an append?

content.raw: Update is the dictionary equivalent of append, since InlineSection is a subclass of OrderedDict. If it’s perferred, an alias could be added for append as update in this case.
content.html: Update is the dictionary equivalent of append, since InlineSection is a subclass of OrderedDict. If it’s perferred, an alias could be added for append as update in this case.

content.raw: This is necessary if you want to add objects of the same type into the same section correct? Maybe the OrderedDict for `input_master` might be better in this case? Having to type the exact index to add to a particular section seems potentially error prone.
content.html: This is necessary if you want to add objects of the same type into the same section correct? Maybe the OrderedDict for input_master might be better in this case? Having to type the exact index to add to a particular section seems potentially error prone.

content.raw: No, you can have the same section appear twice within a single input.master. So for example, you could have two sections with Deterministic CPT’s at the beginning and the end of the file. This was the original justification for having a list instead of an OrderedDict. I think we expected people to start a new section rather than add to an existing one, originally.
content.html: No, you can have the same section appear twice within a single input.master. So for example, you could have two sections with Deterministic CPT’s at the beginning and the end of the file. This was the original justification for having a list instead of an OrderedDict. I think we expected people to start a new section rather than add to an existing one, originally.

content.raw: It would be ideal to get some whitespace between sections
content.html: It would be ideal to get some whitespace between sections

content.raw: Maybe this is worth discussing with @{557058:a9657985-692c-405c-995b-4e41cda7ba2b} , but I think it might be helpful to put a per-line comment/annotation \(when possible\) since these files are generated anyway when written. Something like `# number of CPT objects`, `# cardinality`, `# object index`, etc.
content.html: Maybe this is worth discussing with @Michael Hoffman , but I think it might be helpful to put a per-line comment/annotation (when possible) since these files are generated anyway when written. Something like # number of CPT objects, # cardinality, # object index, etc.

content.raw: `Section` objects should be able to initialize on a single item like `InputMaster` can.
content.html: Section objects should be able to initialize on a single item like InputMaster can.

content.raw:
What happens when input\_master is appended to out-of-order? Does order matter at all? Does it automatically group CPTs for example if I create a `DenseCPT` at the beginning and at the end of the test?

‌
content.html:
What happens when input_master is appended to out-of-order? Does order matter at all? Does it automatically group CPTs for example if I create a DenseCPT at the beginning and at the end of the test?

‌

content.raw: No, InputMaster will print sections in the order that they are given to it. Order does matter for the final file, though at the moment it is up to the user to ensure they add to the master correctly. There is no defined order in input.master files though, rather you just may end up with variables being referenced before being defined.
content.html: No, InputMaster will print sections in the order that they are given to it. Order does matter for the final file, though at the moment it is up to the user to ensure they add to the master correctly. There is no defined order in input.master files though, rather you just may end up with variables being referenced before being defined.

content.raw:
Ideally this piece of code should read like

`input_master[”DENSE_CPT”][”two_dimensional_cpt”] = [[0.25, 0.25], [0.25, 0.25]]` which would do the update and extract the key to be put into a DenseCPT object. You can do this likely through overriding the `__setitem__` method.
content.html:
Ideally this piece of code should read like

input_master[”DENSE_CPT”][”two_dimensional_cpt”] = [[0.25, 0.25], [0.25, 0.25]] which would do the update and extract the key to be put into a DenseCPT object. You can do this likely through overriding the __setitem__ method.

content.raw:
I’m not sure this is possible. Objects need to be the correct type, ie DenseCPT. This wouldn’t work unless you created a function to choose the correct class, then initialized it. Is this something we’d want over just having to do

`input_master[”DENSE_CPT”][”two_dimensional_cpt”] = DenseCPT("two_dinemsional_cpt", [[0.25, 0.25], [0.25, 0.25]])`
content.html:
I’m not sure this is possible. Objects need to be the correct type, ie DenseCPT. This wouldn’t work unless you created a function to choose the correct class, then initialized it. Is this something we’d want over just having to do

input_master[”DENSE_CPT”][”two_dimensional_cpt”] = DenseCPT("two_dinemsional_cpt", [[0.25, 0.25], [0.25, 0.25]])

content.raw:
Yes but if an object is being put into `input_master["DENSE_CPT"]` it would be safe to assume that a DenseCPT object is expected. The `__setitem__` method would create the correct object type for you. The object type can be inferred and then error out of the input data is malformed.

I do think the syntax I suggested is preferred but perhaps @{557058:a9657985-692c-405c-995b-4e41cda7ba2b} has a different opinion
content.html:
Yes but if an object is being put into input_master["DENSE_CPT"] it would be safe to assume that a DenseCPT object is expected. The __setitem__ method would create the correct object type for you. The object type can be inferred and then error out of the input data is malformed.

I do think the syntax I suggested is preferred but perhaps @Michael Hoffman has a different opinion

content.raw: In general, why is `InlineSection` specified every time? If the alternative is in file, presumably the objects would also not be defined for that section? It would be much more streamlined if it could be avoided and internally the API could organize accordingly.
